repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill?

Most Rust releases, our CI breaks as new lints are stabilized, diagnostics change, or  causing confusion and work stoppage.

See #12620 for the latest.

## What solution would you like?

Run all CI jobs against the [beta channel](https://rust-lang.github.io/rustup/concepts/channels.html) of Rust every week.

It's not clear to me the best way to accomplish this or report it to the community at large. IIRC, Github's built-in feature for this only notifies a single person. Filing and tagging an issue would be ideal.

## What alternative(s) have you considered?

Add more checks to CI.

This adds even more time to our already long CI jobs, and will confuse contributors due to failing changes in unrelated code.

issue.body:
## What problem does this solve or what need does it fill?

Bevy uses compile fail tests in [bevy_ecs_compile_fail_tests](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/tree/main/crates/bevy_ecs_compile_fail_tests), `deref_derive`, `deref_mut_derive` and [reflect_derives](https://github.com/bevyengine/bevy/actions/runs/8378534423/job/22943464592?pr=12623#step:6:261) to help ensure that our trait implementations fail as we expect.

However, these regularly break (see #12620 for an example) whenever Rust's diagnostics outputs change.
These aren't real failures (caused by a violation of the invariants we're testing for): they're simply changes to the error messages.

Note that this will affect Bevy devs locally as well, if their version of the Rust toolchain doesn't exactly match the one used in CI.

## What solution would you like?

Parse the diagnostic output to ensure that the key bits of information are correct.

## What alternative(s) have you considered?

We could check only the error number, but this will reduce our ability to detect real and valid failures. We want to know *why* the various traits aren't implemented and ensure it's for the correct reason.

We could also include the rustc toolchain version used to generate the tests, and only run the comparison if the user is on that version. This would help with local failures, but result in a more complex setup and not help us when we update rustc versions in CI.

## Additional context

#12625 discusses how we can catch these errors sooner, but this issue covers how we can avoid them breaking at all.

Swapping from `trybuild` to `ui_test` might make this easier to do.

Thanks to @estebank, @workingjubilee and @compiler-errors for the suggestions and guidance here.
